STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 4, 2021
Jodi Shinn
Ennis Center for Children Inc
20100 Greenfield Road
Detroit, MI 48235
RE: License #: CB740315326
Ennis Center for Children - Port Huron
222 Huron Avenue
Port Huron, MI 48060
Dear Ms. Shinn:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on May 3-18,
2021. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Modified Implementation, Sustainability and Exit Plan (MISEP) requirements, a written
corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules
are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15
days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 For repeat violations, explain why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Alicia Wiggins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 917-1048
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT

License #: CB740315326
Licensee Name: Ennis Center for Children Inc
Licensee Address: 20100 Greenfield Road
Detroit, MI 48235
Licensee Telephone #: (313) 342-2699

Robert Ennis, Designee

Facility Address: 222 Huron Avenue
Port Huron, MI 48060
Facility Telephone #: (810) 990-1424

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12306 Application request.
(4) An agency shall document that the licensee has been given
an application for renewal of the license not less than 60
calendar days before the expiration date of the license.
In one out of six certification records reviewed, the agency did not provide the
licensee an application for renewal of the license not less than 60 calendar days
before the expiration date of the license. The application was mailed to the applicant
on August 26, 2020 and the license expired on October 22, 2020.
R 400.12319 Substitute care policy.
An agency’s substitute care policy shall, at a minimum, contain
provisions for all of the following:
(a) Qualifications for substitute caregivers, consistent with
the requirements of 1973 PA 116 and child care licensing
rules.
In one out of six certification records reviewed, a criminal history clearance for the
foster parent’s substitute caregiver was not completed.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
July 12, 2019
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(7) If any violations are cited and there is a signed corrective
action plan, all social service workers who have children placed
in the home shall be notified there is a corrective action plan
and what is required of the foster parent in that plan.
In one out three special evaluations reviewed, there was no documentation that the
social services worker who had children placed in the home was notified that there
was a CAP and what was required of the foster parent in the CAP.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
4

(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(iii) A physical examination every 14 months.
In one out of eight foster children records reviewed, there was no documentation
that the foster child had a physical examination fourteen months after the last
medical exam. The foster child’s last medical exam was completed on December
13, 2019.
R 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement to a
youth before placement in independent living.
In one out of two independent living records reviewed, there was no documentation
that the agency gave a copy of the program statement to the youth before placement
in independent living.
R 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living with a
copy of the agency’s policies and procedures required by this
rule.
In one out of two independent living records reviewed, there was no documentation
that the agency provided the youth in independent living with a copy of the agency’s
policies and procedures required by this rule.
R 400.12507 Medical/dental and mental health care.
(1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent living
receives any needed medical, dental, and mental health care as
required in R 400.12413. Medical, dental, and mental health
care provided shall be documented in the youth’s record.
In one out of two independent living records reviewed, the last medical exam the
youth had was on August 1, 2019. The last dental exam the youth had was not
signed but it was dated on April 30, 2019.
R 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information
and documentation, which shall be recorded within 30 calendar
days after placement in independent living and updated at least
once every 90 calendar days:
(o) Service plans as required in R 400.12419 and R
400.12420. If the youth has biological children, the service
5

plan must address the living arrangement for the child or
children, visitation/parenting time with the youth’s biological
children or a clear explanation why this is not possible or
appropriate.
In one out of two independent living records reviewed, all of the updated service
plans were not completed every 90 calendar days. One updated service plan was
due on February 25, 2021 and it was completed on March 12, 2021.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
In one out of two independent living records reviewed, there was no documentation
that the independent living contract was reviewed and updated at least once every
90 calendar days and a copy provided to the youth. The last independent living
contract was signed on December 16, 2020.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
DHHS Policy Relative Engagement and Placement: Relative Placement
FOM 722-03B Home Study Annual Review.
The Relative Placement Home Study including all clearances
must be completed and approved annually (within 365 days of
the previous Relative Placement Home Study completion date)
for unlicensed caregivers. An approved Relative Placement
Home Study is valid for one year.
In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, which was placed with a
relative, the annual relative home study was not completed. The annual relative
home study was due by April 30, 2021.
DHHS Policy Family Team Meetings: Types and Timeframes.
FOM 722-06B
The following events shall trigger FTM for out of home cases:
 Case Plan Development/ Reassessment:
6

Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
 Semi-Annual Transition Meeting - within 30 calendar
days after the youth’s 14th birthday and every six months
thereafter. For youth entering out-of-home placement at
age 14 or older, the semi-annual transition meeting must
be held within 30 calendar days of the removal date.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting (FTM)
Report, must be completed for every FTM.
The DHS-901, Semi-Annual Transition Plan Report, must be
updated to reflect progress toward goals during each meeting.
In three out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, FTMs were not completed
timely.
 For one record, the activity report for the October 12, 2020 FTM was not
completed. The semi-annual transition FTMs were not completed every six
months. Semi-annual transition FTMs were completed on July 7, 2020 and
April 14, 2021.
 For one record, a FTM for case service plan development for the USP ending
on February 10. 2021 was not completed within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
 For one record, the activity report for the October 23, 2020 FTM was not
completed.
In one out of two independent living record reviewed, FTMs were not completed
timely. A FTM for case service plan development for the USP ending on November
27, 2020 was not completed. The activity report for the January 15, 2021 FTM was
not completed. The semi-annual transition FTMs were not completed every six
months. Semi-annual transition FTMs were completed on November 7, 2019 and
January 15, 2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
July 12, 2019
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2020 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
March 17, 2020
DHHS Policy Efforts to Identify and Locate Absent/Putative Parent(s).
FOM 722-06G
7

Location efforts must be documented in all case service plans
and in the social work contacts section of the case service plan.
In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, in which there was an absent
parent, the efforts to locate the birth mother were not documented in the case
service plans and in the social work contacts section of the case service plan from
September 2020 to March 2021.
DHHS Policy Timely Entry of Case Contacts.
FOM 722-06H
All caseworker contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS; this
includes attempted contacts and missed appointments, and all
pertinent information obtained must be summarized and
included in the appropriate section of the case service plan.
All face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS, within
five business days of the contact. This includes the following:
• Any face-to-face contacts with children, parents, or
caregivers made by any of the following:
• Foster care worker.
• CPS worker.
• Adoption worker.
• Permanency resource monitors.
• Parent/child face-to-face contacts.
• Sibling/child face-to face contacts.
8

In four out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, all contacts were not entered
in MiSACWIS within five business days of the contact.
 For one foster child’s record, the face-to-face contact with the mother in
December 2020 was completed on December 17, 2020 and it was entered in
MiSACWIS on May 13, 2021. The contact with the mother in January 2021
was completed on January 22, 2021 and it was entered in MiSACWIS on May
12, 2021. The contact with the mother in February 2021 was completed on
February 3, 2021 and it was entered in MiSACWIS on May 13, 2021. The
April 2021 sibling visit was completed on April 26, 2021 and it was entered in
MiSACWIS on May 11, 2021.
 For one foster child’s record, the contact with the foster child and caregiver
was completed on December 10, 2020 and it was entered in MiSACWIS on
May 12, 2021.
 For one foster child’s record, the sibling visit in September 2020 was
completed on September 4, 2020 and it was entered in MiSACWIS on May
12, 2021.
 For one foster child’s record, the sibling visit in April 2021 was completed on
April 24, 2021 and it was entered on May 17, 2021.
DHHS Policy Maintaining Connections through Visitation and Contact:
FOM 722-06I Sibling Visitation and Ongoing Interaction.
Siblings in foster care, who are not placed together, must have
at least one visit per calendar month that is in addition to
parenting time.
In one out of two independent living records reviewed, there was no documentation
that sibling visits occurred in November 2020 and February 2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
July 12, 2019
DHHS Policy Foster Care Parent Agency Treatment Plan and Service
FOM 722-08C Agreement (Signatures).
For both ISP and USP, the PATP must be signed by the worker,
supervisor, parent(s), foster parents/caregivers, and children 14
years and older.
9

In two out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, the PATPs did not contain
all of the required signatures.
 For one foster child’s records, the PATPs for USPs ending on May 8, 2020
and August 3, 2020 were not signed by the caregiver.
 For one foster child’s record, the PATPs for the ISP and USPs ending on
October 28, 2020 and January 26, 2021 were not signed by the father.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
July 12, 2019
DHHS Policy Foster Care – Updated Service Plan. (Supervisory
FOM 722-09 Approval)
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
 Review and approve the USP within fourteen calendar
days of the report date.
In four out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, the USPs were not approved
by the supervisor within fourteen calendar days of the report date.
 For one record, one report was completed on August 8, 2020 and it was
approved on August 23, 2020. One report was completed on November 6, 2020 and
it was approved on November 21, 2020.
 For one record, one report was completed on January 23, 2021 and it was
approved on February 8, 2021.
 For one record, one report was completed on November 12, 2020 and it was
approved on December 16, 2020. One report was completed on February 10,
2021 and it was approved on March 12, 2021.
 For one record, the report was completed on January 26, 2021 and it was
approved on February 22, 2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
July 12, 2019
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2020 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
March 17, 2020
DHHS Policy Health Requirements: Dental Examination Schedule.
FOM 801-01
Dental examinations are required for children one year of age
and older, as follows:
 A dental examination within three months before entry
into foster care or an initial dental examination shall be
completed not more than 90 calendar days after entry
into a foster care out-of-home placement.
10

 A dental re-examination shall be obtained at least every
six months, unless a greater frequency is indicated.
In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, a dental re-examination was
not completed at least every six months. The last dental exam was completed on
February 3, 2020.
DHHS Policy Medical Passport.
FOM 801-03
Initial Medical Passport
For children entering foster care, the initial medical passport
must be provided within two weeks of the child/youth's
placement date to the following:
 Foster care provider.
Updated Medical Passport.
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary
court ward.
Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider:
At or prior to each placement.
Quarterly.
11

In three out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, the medical passports were
not provided to the required persons per policy.
 For one record, an updated medical passport was not signed by the foster
parent at or prior to the time the foster child was replaced on July 31, 2020.
 For one record, the medical passport was not signed by the foster parent
within two weeks of the foster child being placed in the home. The medical
passport was not signed by the relative at or prior to the time the foster child
was replaced on July 15, 2020.
 For one record, the medical passport was not signed by the parent within two
weeks of the child being placed with his father and the medical passport was
not updated quarterly. The child was placed with his father on July 1, 2020
and the father signed the medical passport on November 23, 2020 and
February 11, 2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
July 12, 2019
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2020 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
March 17, 2020
DHHS Policy Child Adoption Assessment.
ADM 300
The DHS-1927, Child Adoption Assessment, must be completed
by the adoption worker and approved by the adoption
supervisor within 45 calendar days of case acceptance. The
adoption worker must verify that the information provided
through the foster care DHS-65, Initial Service Plan (ISP), and
DHS-66, Updated Service Plans (USP), is correct and include
all additional information required on the assessment form. Prior
to completing the child adoption assessment, the adoption
worker must make a minimum of two face-to-face contacts with
the child, with at least one in the home, and one face-to-face
with the child's current caregiver, even if the caregiver(s) are not
interested in adopting the child. The contacts must be
documented in the child assessment.
12

In two out of eight adoption children’s records reviewed, the child adoption
assessments were not completed within 45 calendar days of the case acceptance.
 For one record, the case was accepted on March 17, 2021 and the
assessment was not completed.
 For one record, the case was accepted on March 18, 2020 and the
assessment was completed on May 12, 2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
July 12, 2019
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2020 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
March 17, 2020
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was not offered technical assistance.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during
this licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
One CAP was in response to the 2020 Renewal Inspection findings.
During the inspection entrance meeting, the chief administrator discussed her
findings, which were consistent with the findings of the inspection.
The staff and supervisors interviewed reported no concerns with the program. They
indicated that they continue to do everything they can to provide the best services to
the children and families that they serve despite the current pandemic causing some
challenges in available services. They reported the agency works well together as a
team and the support that they provide to each other has resulted in improved
compliance with licensing and policy requirements. This was reflected in the
inspection results.
VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
13

There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, I recommend that the facility continue
on a regular license.
May 28, 2021
________________________________________
Alicia Wiggins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
June 4, 2021

Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
